qas.question: By what method do humans often try to control the spread of insects?
What portion of the biosphere would be devastated absent the complex pollination role of insects?
What insect provides a tangible economic benefit via the production of silk?
What insect is known to consume carrion?
Humans consider most insects as what?
Humans can control insects using what?
Insects have the potential to damage what?
Insects can damage crops by feeing on sap, fruits, or what?
Silkworms are used by humans for producing what?

context: Humans regard certain insects as <a4_0>pests<a4_0/>, and attempt to control them using <a0_0><a5_0>insecticides<a5_0/><a0_0/> and a host of other techniques. Some insects damage <a6_0>crops<a6_0/> by feeding on sap, <a7_0>leaves<a7_0/> or fruits. A few parasitic species are pathogenic. Some insects perform complex ecological roles; <a3_0>blow-flies<a3_0/>, for example, help consume carrion but also spread diseases. Insect pollinators are essential to the life-cycle of many flowering plant species on which most organisms, including humans, are at least partly dependent; without them, the <a1_0>terrestrial<a1_0/> portion of the biosphere (including humans) would be devastated. Many other insects are considered ecologically beneficial as predators and a few provide direct economic benefit. <a2_0>Silkworms<a2_0/> and bees have been used extensively by humans for the production of <a8_0>silk<a8_0/> and honey, respectively. In some cultures, people eat the larvae or adults of certain insects.
